text: I was actually just thinking the other day about how great a language Julia is for academic writing or note taking - meaning, with tools like `Latexify.jl` and `Literate.jl` and `Weave.jl`, `.jmd` files, Julia's unicode notation, and easy access to the system clipboard or even piping, writing up code ideas becomes a breeze. Sorry to put you on the spot, but I just saw a somewhat unifying package being written by <@U01BTNDCUBX> called `Books.jl` . It looks amazing! Could you talk about it some Rik? Thanks! (link: <https://github.com/rikhuijzer/Books.jl>)

text: Thanks for the kinds words. Basically, I never set out to make this package. It was/is just something what I need for my PhD since I need to generate a lot of reports and dashboards. So, I started hacking a website together with Pandoc and LiveServer. That worked well and here we are. For some reason, all the parts in Books.jl happend to fit in nicely. I’m already happily using it “in production” so to say. By the way, this package isn’t meant to be a competitor for Franklin. I’m really looking forward to the progress <@U9EDKCNBF> and many others are making on the pure Julia conversions, that is, non-pandoc.
